QUESTION.QUESTION_DESCRIPTION:
Make a normalized database model (table structure) based on below ER Diagram and information

Note: In ER Diagram M:N represents Ordinality:Cardinality. Ordinality specifies optional or mandatory, Cardinality specifies one or many

Above ER diagram represents entities of a Sandwich shop

  1. The Sandwich shop has many employees who sells sandwiches
  2. Each sale done by the employee is recorded with it's date and items(Sandwiches) sold 
  3. Each of the sandwich has a name, size and price associated with it
Present the final database table structure as your in following format

Table Name 1 (column name 1, column name 2...)
Table Name 2 (column name 1, column name 2...)
...
...

Refer Customer table  below
Customers (Customer_id, Name, City, State, Country, Phone, Email, JoinDate)

1) Write a SQL query to get names of customer who have not provided their Email
Output expected:
Name
Aakash
Amber
Aman

2) Write a SQL query to get names and Emails of customers who have their emails at gmail.com with Emails in descending order

Output expected:
Name                Email
Amber Amber@gmail.com
Aman Aman@gmail.com
Aakash Aakash@gmail.com


3) Write a SQL query to get country-wise count of  customers with ascending order of countries

Output expected:
Country                CustomerCount
India           5
Russia   2000
USA           100
How does De-fragmentation help in increasing the execution speed of a program running within an Operating System? Please also explain why Linux does not need De-fragmentation

  • IP Address
  • Subnet Mask

Describe what is DNS and how is it used when you browse a website (e.g. www.gmail.com) using a browser

QUESTION.QUESTION_DESCRIPTION: Explain pass-by-value and pass-by-reference concept. Take suitable Java examples to illustrate the concept and its usage

Write a Java Class which will remove any given character from a String. Assume that a string and a character will be send to your API and you are expected to return the string after removing the character that is provided

Below the declaration for the method which needs to be implemented in this Class
Public String shortenedString (String inputData, char charcterToBeRemoved);

Example data 
  • Input: (Greetings, e), Output: Grtings
  • Input: (Amazing, a), Output: mzing

You are expected to
  • Write the method implementation code
  • Call the method with sample data from main method
Please write professional code i.e.
  • Follow proper naming conventions
  • Add necessary checks for bad input e.g. null/ empty check, test for not null, zero input etc
  • Perform appropriate exception handling as needed

Write a Java program that will return whichever value is nearest to the value of 100 from two given integer numbers

Below is the method declaration which needs to be implemented by the program
Public int whoIsNearMe (int number1, int number2)

Example data
  • Input: (70, 125), Output: 125
  • Input: (70,60), Output: 70
You are expected to
  • Write the method implementation code
  • Call the method with sample data from main method
Please write professional code i.e.
  • Follow proper naming conventions
  • Add necessary checks for bad input e.g. null/ empty check, test for not null, zero input etc
  • Perform appropriate exception handling as needed

Write Java Class BankAccount which manages account balance. The BackAccount class provides method to handle deposits and withdrawals in the account. Below interface needs to be implemented by this class


     public Interface BankAccountInterface
     {
          public void deposit(int amount);

          public void withdraw(int amount);
     }

Please take care of following
  • This Class will be used in multi-threaded application and these methods might be called by many threads at the same time
  • Please ensure the balance in the account always remains consistent based on the deposits and withdrawals
You are expected to
  • Write the method implementation code
  • Call the method with sample data from main method
Please write professional code i.e.
  • Follow proper naming conventions
  • Add necessary checks for bad input e.g. null/ empty check, test for not null, zero input etc
  • Perform appropriate exception handling as needed
